title: About
text: Welcome to the middle of the film.

title: About Sam Kestin
text:
Read Sam’s Leksikon fun Yidishn Teater entry.


Listen to Sam sing! Click on the album images below to be directed to the song information and recording.






Shtetl Amerike   


Ikh bin sherif   


Kolombus’s medine   


Ikh beink zurik kein New York   







Click on any picture below to scroll through them as a photo gallery.

































Photograph of Sam taken in Chicago, time unknown









Family photograph of Sam Kestin







Sam in his role in Der Griner Milyoner (Chapter 42 in memoirs)







Sam (far right) performing in Dos Tsubrokhene Fidele (Chapter 43 in memoirs)







Sam (far right) performing in Dos Tsubrokhene Fidele (Chapter 43 in memoirs)









Sam performing with Molly Picon in Hello Molly in the 1928/29 season, Second Avenue Theater.







Sam performing with Molly Picon in the 1928/29 season, Second Avenue Theater, play unknown. According to the caption, in this scene she asks (in English, transliterated into Yiddish): “Hello Papa, how is your rheumatism?”







Sam performing with Molly Picon (left) and Betty Simonoff (middle) in the 1928/29 season, Second Avenue Theater, play unknown. According to the caption, Sam and Molly play father and son, and in this scene they confess their love for the Russian princess (played by Betty) as she sings Romanian songs.







Sam performing with Molly Picon (left) and Betty Simonoff (middle) in The Circus Girl during the 1928/29 season, Second Avenue Theater.









Sam performing with Annie Thomashefsky (one of Boris Thomashefsky’s sisters) in The Happy Village in 1937, Second Avenue Theater.







Artist’s rendering of Sam (1907)







Cartoon by Saul Raskin of the cast of Earth, Heaven, and Trickery, with Sam on the bottom right. (Source)







Cartoon by Zuni Maud of the cast of The Doctor’s Wife by Leon Kobrin, with Sam second from the left.








Photograph of Sam taken in Chicago, time unknown
Family photograph of Sam Kestin
Sam in his role in Der Griner Milyoner (Chapter 42 in memoirs)
Sam (far right) performing in Dos Tsubrokhene Fidele (Chapter 43 in memoirs)

According to the caption, Sam and Molly play father and son, and in this scene they confess their love for the Russian princess (played by Betty) as she sings Romanian songs.
Sam performing with Molly Picon (left) and Betty Simonoff (middle) in The Circus Girl during the 1928/29 season, Second Avenue Theater.
